item.title: Drones Embody an Iran-Russia Alliance Built on Hostility to the U.S.
item.description: Authoritarian regimes in Moscow and Tehran have in common international isolation, domestic crisis and conflict with the West.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A drone believed to be an Iranian Shahed-136 nearing its target in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: As Europe Piles Sanctions on Russia, Some Sacred Cows Are Spared
item.description: The European Union has been severing economic ties with Moscow to support Ukraine, but some countries have lobbied to protect key sectors.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Virginie Nguyen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rough diamonds, a lucrative export for Russia, are shipped to the Belgian city of Antwerp, an important diamond hub.

item.title: A Military Jet Crashed in Southern Russia, Killing At Least Four
item.description: Russian military officials said the jet was on a training flight when one of its engines caught fire, causing it to crash in a port town about 25 miles from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Randy Pennell and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: The site of a plane crash at a residential building in the southern city of Yeysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Republicans Gain Edge as Voters Worry About Economy, Times/Siena Poll Finds
item.description: With elections next month, independents, especially women, are swinging to the G.O.P. despite Democrats’ focus on abortion rights. Disapproval of President Biden seems to be hurting his party.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the Utah Senate Debate
item.description: Senator Mike Lee and Evan McMullin sparred about Donald Trump and Jan. 6, and had common ground on abortion.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Rick Bowmer/Associated Press
item.media:description: Senator Mike Lee of Utah, a Republican, with Evan McMullin, left, his independent rival, before their debate on Monday night in Orem, Utah.

item.title: The Problem of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: What the rise of the far-right congresswoman means for the House, the G.O.P. and the nation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Stephen Voss for The New York Times

item.title: The House Jan. 6 Panel Has Set a High Bar: Showing Criminality
item.description: The committee investigating the attack on the Capitol has yet to decide on making criminal referrals. But its decision to subpoena Donald Trump is in keeping with its prosecutorial style.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: In suggesting that its goal is to spur criminal charges, the Jan. 6 committee is setting a standard for success that is beyond its power to carry out.

item.title: Trump Hotels Charged Secret Service Exorbitant Rates, House Inquiry Finds
item.description: Records obtained by the House Oversight Committee show the former president’s properties charged more than $1.4 million to agents protecting him and his family.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes Case Takes On More Drama Ahead of Sentencing
item.description: Ms. Holmes, founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, asked for a new trial after a surprise visit from a key witness to her house.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth Holmes arriving her father, Christian Holmes, left, and her partner, Billy Evans, at the U.S. courthouse in San Jose, Calif., for a hearing in her case on Monday.

item.title: Shehan Karunatilaka Wins Booker Prize for ‘The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida’
item.description: The Sri Lankan writer received the award, one of the most prestigious literary prizes in the world, for his second novel, which examines the trauma of his country’s decades-long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.category: The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida (Book)
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shehan Karunatilaka in London last month. His second novel received the Booker Prize on Monday.

item.title: It’s Not a Diwali Celebration Without Mithai
item.description: We visited five South Asian sweet shops across the United States as they prepare colorful treats for one of their biggest days of the year.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maharaja Sweets, one of New York City’s most beloved South Asian sweet shops, does brisk business on Diwali.

item.title: Preparing for Republican Debt Blackmail
item.description: Democrats should do whatever it takes to block extortion.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: Britain’s Liz Truss Is Finished
item.description: Britain’s prime minister may limp on, powerless, but she will fall.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Gold
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Daniel Leal, via Getty Images

item.title: The Fall of Liz Cheney and the Rise of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: The Jan. 6 hearings were the final hurrah for Decent Republicans.

item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
Weapons of Mass Delusion: When the Republican Party Lost Its Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor Greene, ascendant in the Republican Party.

item.title: A New Playbook for Saving Democracy, Defeating Fascism and Winning Elections
item.description: In the longer contest to tell the better story about America and draw people into that story, there is a great worry among organizers that the left is badly falling short.
item.dc:creator: Anand Giridharadas
item.media:credit: Jon Han

item.title: Unseparate and Unequal
item.description: Workers may have more leverage these days, but the boss is still the boss.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy

item.title: Imagining a Post-Global World
item.description: The chaos that’s engulfed the economy is driven by a seismic shift toward a better balance between the global and the local.
item.dc:creator: Rana Foroohar

item.title: Welcome to the Madness of Our Trumpy, Trumpy World
item.description: How much will the Supreme Court change the world?
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Grutter v. Bollinger’s affirmation of affirmative action may well be the next precedent to fall.

item.title: Wait, Who Did You Say Is Middle-Aged?
item.description: Boomers didn’t appreciate getting long in the tooth. But as a Gen Xer, I have to assume it’s worse for us.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drones struck Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, early this morning.

item.title: Food waste solutions
item.description: Around the world, lawmakers and entrepreneurs are taking steps to tackle two of humanity’s most pressing problems: hunger and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: A smart composing bin for residential drop-off in Queens, New York City.

item.title: Meta’s Quest Pro, Gig Economy Workers and Shocking A.I. News
item.description: Big tech is staring down the future.

item.title: Biden Opens Applications for Student Loan Forgiveness
item.description: The government hopes to help tens of millions of borrowers before federal student loan payments are due again in January.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with Education Secretary Miguel A. Cardona at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Hair Straighteners May Pose a Small Risk for Uterine Cancer, Study Finds
item.description: A national study suggests a link to this particular cancer among women who reported frequent use of the chemical products.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: Nigeria Floods Kill Hundreds and Displace Over a Million
item.description: The country is experiencing its worst floods in years, damaging homes, infrastructure and vast sections of farmland.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Vehicles on an unflooded road in Lokoja, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The floods have partly or wholly destroyed farmland, infrastructure and 200,000 homes.

item.title: Four Friends Missing in Oklahoma Found Dismembered, Police Say
item.description: A witness had been invited to join the men to “hit a lick big enough for all of them,” or to engage in some kind of criminal behavior, a police chief said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: How to Stay Safe From Covid This Holiday Season
item.description: As our third pandemic winter approaches, you can mitigate risk without missing out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How to Get Rid of Bad Breath
item.description: Food choices, oral hygiene habits and certain health conditions can play a role — but there are ways to keep dragon breath in check.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Pablo Delcan; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: ‘Kind of Awkward’: Doctors Find Themselves on a First-Name Basis
item.description: While many physicians may avoid discussing the subject, a study showed that who gets addressed with the honorific “Dr.” may depend on gender, degree and specialty.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Use of formal titles in medicine and many other professions is a linguistic signal of respect and professionalism,” two doctors wrote.

item.title: Dwayne Johnson Is Ready to Embrace the Heel Again in ‘Black Adam’
item.description: In his wrestling days, he played the baddie. Now the action star is known for good-guy roles. He explains why he pushed so hard to play the DC antihero.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dwayne Johnson wasn’t bothered by Black Adam’s scoundrel status: “What’s critical is the investment in more superhero characters of color, and Black Adam is one of them.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
